programming_knowledge.book_title: NSCA's Essentials of Strength Training and Conditioning (4th Ed.)
programming_knowledge.author: G. Gregory Haff & N. Travis Triplett
programming_knowledge.title: Evidence-Based Periodization for Athletic Performance
programming_knowledge.description: Systematic organization of training variables (volume, intensity, frequency) to optimize performance peaks. Meta-analysis of 23 studies shows 28% greater performance improvements with periodized vs non-periodized training. The NSCA model integrates linear, undulating, and conjugate methods based on sport demands.
research_citations: Hartmann et al. (2009): Systematic review training organization
Stone et al. (2007): Athletic performance periodization

programming_knowledge.author: Mel Siff & Yuri Verkhoshansky
programming_knowledge.title: Special Strength Training Classification System
programming_knowledge.description: Verkhoshansky's classification of strength qualities: maximal strength, speed-strength, strength-speed, explosive strength, reactive strength, and strength endurance. Each requires specific training methods, loading parameters, and movement velocities for optimal development and sport transfer.

programming_knowledge.book_title: Low Back Disorders: Evidence-Based Prevention and Rehabilitation (3rd Ed.)
programming_knowledge.author: Stuart McGill
programming_knowledge.title: Evidence-Based Spine Stability Training
programming_knowledge.description: McGill's 30+ years research establishes spine stability through endurance rather than strength. Clinical studies show 76% reduction in low back pain recurrence using evidence-based protocols. The approach respects individual movement patterns and tissue tolerance while building functional stability.
research_citations: McGill et al. (2009): Spine stability exercise analysis
Kavcic et al. (2004): Individual torso muscle roles

intervention.progression: Based on symptom response and function

programming_knowledge.author: Christophe Hausswirth & IÃ±igo Mujika
programming_knowledge.title: Evidence-Based Recovery Strategies for Athletic Performance
programming_knowledge.description: Systematic analysis of recovery modalities from 30+ international experts. Research demonstrates recovery interventions can improve next-day performance by 8-15% when properly applied. The approach integrates passive, active, and psychological recovery methods based on training load and competition demands.
research_citations: Kellmann & Beckmann (2003): Sport psychology of recovery
